bestBHT.bht: If one could face the doom of death for violating Moses' law, how much more deserving of punishment is the one who fully disregards the gospel? Apostasy, the utter violation of the old covenant, equates to a complete denial of Christ. Just as transgressors under the law died without mercy, those who renounce Christ find no provision for pardon. The severity of judgment without mercy is highlighted by the principle of multiple witnesses from the law.

Henry Alford: If Moses' law could attach to violations of it the inexorable doom of death...
The reference is especially to Deut. xvii. 2–7, where the punishment of death is attached to the same sin as is here in question...
(the allusion is to Deut. as above, where it is thus prescribed)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: set at naught" [ALFORD]: utterly and heinously violated, not merely some minor detail, but the whole law and covenant.
apostasy answers to such an utter violation of the old covenant.
removal out of the pale of mitigation, or a respite of his doom.
Albert Barnes: The subject of apostasy from the Christian religion is particularly under discussion here, and it was natural to illustrate this by a reference to a similar case under the Law of Moses.
Died without mercy - That is, there was no provision for pardon.

The 'principle' in the Law was, that it was to be presumed that two or three persons would be much less likely to conspire to render a false testimony than one would be, and that two or three would not be likely to be deceived in regard to a fact which they had observed.
Marvin Vincent: He that despised [αφετησας τις]. Lit. one that despised; any transgressor.
Died [αποθνησκει]. Lit. dieth. According to the ordinance as it now stands in the law.
Without mercy [χωρις οικτιρμων]. The phrase N. T. o. For the noun see on 2 Corinthians 1:3.
John Calvin: This is an argument from the less to the greater... how much heavier punishment does the rejection of the gospel deserve, a sin which involves so many and so heinous impieties!
He speaks not of particular sins, but of the entire denial of Christ; for the Law did not punish all kinds of transgressions with death, but apostasy...
We hence learn what sort of crime the Apostle meant... it is beyond all dispute that he speaks of apostasy.
Philip Schaff: This awful destiny which awaits wilful apostates, judgment without mercy, is now illustrated and enforced from the law.
Moses’ Law attached to certain violations of it the doom of death.

Apostasy from Christ answers to the wilful, deliberate idolatry of the Law, and is the sin condemned here with a condemnation proportioned to the fuller light and the greater privileges of the Gospel.
Archibald T. Robertson: On the basis of two or three (επ δυσιν η τρισιν).
John Gill: died without mercy; a corporeal death; there was no atonement nor sacrifice for him, nor pity to be shown him, Deuteronomy 13:8.
Under two or three witnesses; who 'stood by', or were present, as the Arabic version renders it, when the transgression was committed.
that were witnesses against him, and plainly and fully proved the fact, Deuteronomy 17:6.
John Wesley: He that, in capital cases, despised (presumptuously transgressed) the law of Moses died without mercy - Without any delay or mitigation of his punishment.

bhtAttempts.bht: If someone under Moses' law could face death for violating it, how much more deserving of punishment is the one who fully disregards the gospel? The verse alludes to the punishment of death from Deuteronomy, emphasizing the severity of the sin, specifically apostasy, which equates to a complete violation of the old covenant. Just as there was no mercy or respite for transgressors under the law, there is no provision for pardon for those who renounce Christ. The principle of multiple witnesses from the law is used to illustrate the severity of the judgment without mercy. This passage warns against the weighty condemnation that awaits those who reject the gospel, a sin that surpasses all others in impiety.

If the disobedience of Moses' law led to death without clemency, how much more deserving of punishment is the one who utterly violates the old covenant? Apostasy, the complete denial of Christ, is the sin condemned here, with condemnation proportional to the abundant light and privileges of the Gospel. Just as there was no atonement or pity for transgressors under the law, those who renounce Christ find no provision for pardon. The severity of judgment without mercy is emphasized through the principle of multiple witnesses from the law.

The punishment of death in the Old Testament law serves as a warning of the more severe judgment awaiting those who fully disregard the gospel. Apostasy, the complete denial of Christ, corresponds to the deliberate idolatry of the Law, deserving condemnation in proportion to the greater light and privileges of the Gospel. Just as transgressors under the law died without mercy, those who reject Christ find no provision for pardon. The principle of multiple witnesses from the law further illustrates the weightiness of the judgment without mercy.
